coredata.dc:title: X-ray investigation of CoCl bonding in a concentrated aqueous solution of CoCl2 and LiCl
coredata.dc:creator: Paschina, G.
Piccaluga, G.
Pinna, G.
Magini, M.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A concentrated CO(II) solution with a Cl−/Co2+ ratio of≈4 was examined by X-ray diffraction. The Fourier-transformed scattering data indicated inner complex formation between Co2+ and Cl−ions. The overall coordination of Co2+ ions is very close to 6 and the average number of bonded Cl− ions per cobalt atom was found to be nearly 1. The similarity of this result to the one obtained from a solution of NiCl2 of equal concentration is discussed. This result was also checked through EXAFS measurements.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 98. number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 June 1983 X-RAY INVESTIGATION OF Co-Cl BONDING IN A CONCENTRATED AQUEOUS SOLUTION OF CoCI^ AND Lid G. PASCHINA, G. PICCALUGA. G. PINNA Istimto di Chimica Fisica e Industriale. Universite, Via Ospedale 72, 09100 Cagliari, Italy and M. MAGINI Divisione Clliinica, TIB. ENEA, 00060 Casaccia. Rome. Italy Received 12 March 1983: in final form 18 April 1983 A concentrated Co(II) solution Ui itii a Cl'/Co2'1" ratio of 4 was examined by X-ray diffraction. Tlie Fourier-transformed scattering data indicated inner complex formation bet\\ een Co2'1" and Cl~ ions. The overall coordination of Co2* ions is very close to 6 and the average number of bonded Cl~ ions per cobalt atom \^as found to be nearh 1. Tlie .imil.iriiv of this result to the one obtained from a solution of NiCl^ of equal concentration is discussed. This result was also checked through EXAFS measurements. 1. Introduction It is well known that divalent nickel is not absorbed appreciable from chloride solutions by liquid anion exchangers while divalent cobalt is well absorbed. In order to understand the origins of this selectivity, we started a study aiming at determining the nature of the species occurring in Ni(II) and Co(II) chloride so- lutions. Stoichiometric concentrated (^3 mol S~1) solutions ofCod^ and NiCh were first [1] investi- gated by X-ray diffraction. For both solutions the presence of a considerable amount (:= 50%) of the species Me(H^O)5Cl+, in equilibrium with the hexa- aquo ions MeCH^O)^, was suggested. This descrip- tion was slightly favoured with respect to an old one [2] m which Ni2'1" ions in concentrated solutions were only considered to be involved in the hexa-aquo form. In any case, in the solutions examined in ref. [ 1 ], Co2"1' and Ni24" ions have almost identical behaviour towards Cl~ complexation. Later three concentrated Ni(II) solutions were ex- amined [3] by X-ray diffraction with CF/Ni2"1' ratios of 4 and 5, obtained by suitable addition of Lia or HC1 to the Stoichiometric solution (%s2 mol fi~^ in Nidi). The average number of bonded chloride ions per nickel atom ("Ni2 l-_cr) \vas found to be in the range 0.92-1.43; octahedral NiO^O^^Ci2"" (n = 0,1.2) complexes are the species consistent \i ith these average chloride coordinations and with the distribu- tion and structure functions. The same solutions have recently been [4] investi- gated by EXAFS spectroscopy. Tlie energy range around the K absorption edge ot'Ni(II) was examined in order to study the mean environment of the cation without the trouble due to the overlap of anion and solvent pair distribution functions. Tile results ob- tained by X-ray diffraction were substantially con- firmed. Tlie presence of Cl" ions in the first cationic coordination shell was again evidenced; the quantity "Ni^-cris in an interval of slightly lower values (0.7 1.0), but, in the light of the uncertainties of both techniques in the determination of the coordination numbers [3,4], it is not clear if the observed differ- ence is meaningful. In the present work tlie research has been extended to a solution ofCoCI-, (=^2 mol fi~^ in Cod-)), exriched in chloride ions by addition of UC1 up to the ratio CP/Ni2"*- 4 (the value of 5 was prevented by salt solubility). The sample was ex- 0 009-2614/83/0000-0000/S 03.00 1983 North-Holland 157 Volume 98. number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 June 1983 Volume 98, numbei amined by X-ray diffraction at room temperature. The results obtained were also checked through EXAFS measurements on the same sample. 1. Experimental and data treatment The solution \\as prepared from reagent-grade CoCl->-6H->Oand Lid and its composition determined by standard volumetric methods. The density, mea- sured \\ith a digital precision densitometer, turned out to be 1.275 g/ml. The composition was expressed as .v in (CoCl3)^(LiCl)3 i9y(H30)i_Y,.Y being 0.037. The X-ray apparatus and the data normalization procedures have been described [5.6]. The basic for- mulas are reported here. The radial distribution curve D(r) and the correla- tion function G(r) \\erc calculated from the structur- ally sensitive part of the scattering data. iCs). by a Fourier transfoimation according to: G(r)= D(r} ^-PQ 27T^p ; f s i(s) sin(rs) ds. (1) Here r is the interatomic dislance. PQ is tlie average bulk density of stoichiometric units, s is the usual scattering variable (s = 47r sin i9/A. where o is half the scattering angle and X is the wavelength of the radia- tion employed. MoKa). ^ (0.65 A~ ^and s,na^(l 5.98 A~1} are the lo\\er and upper limits of the experimen- tal data. The structure function i(s) is defined as m m '^"(^""^-^K^-^- (2) where tlie^ are the scattering factors corrected for anomalous dispersion..v, are the stoichiometric co- efficients in a structural unit containing m kinds of atoms, /py is the intensity in electron units. In order to evaluate the 7^ function from the ex- perimental intensities the normalization method pro- posed by Habenschuss and Spedding [7] was employed. Small peaks below 1.5 A which appeared in the G'(r) curve were removed, since they do not correspond to any real interatomic distance. The experimental struc- ture function i(s) multiplied by s and the G(r) curve thus deduced are shown in figs. 1 and 2 respectively (dots). Fig 1- E.\perimenial (...) and model ( ) structure functions. The "model" s i(s) is calculated \iilh Hie parameters reported in table 1. column 2 rig 2 Experimental (..) and model ( ) correlation func- tions The "model" G(r) is calculated with the parameters reported in table 1. column 2. 3. Results and discussion The atomic radial distribution shown in ssg. 2 ap- pears very similar to the one reported for the corre- sponding solution of NiCI^ [3]. The G(r) function ex- hibits two prominent peaks around 2.1 A and 3-15 3.20 A. These distances are those expected for the pairs Co^-H^O and Cr-HaO, both on the basis of the radii of the species and literature information [ 1,3]. Under the first peak the small contribution from the interaction Li^-H^O (occurring at 2.0-2.1 A) [3,8,9] is included. Betw theCr-H^Oin) observable at %2 results obtained u this shoulder is li] direct contacts. 1 contains several c phenomena beyo In order to ha' nearest-neighbou] structure functiol part of the s i(s) l from the shortest thetic structure fi modified Debye f analysis of diffrac phous substances pared with the ex squares procedun lations were thos< H^o-H^o.cr- tions (the H^O-l actions within thf ions, between wa tion shells and so the Cl" ion was s several X-ray and [3,6,11]. As far a dination number in a combined stui was adopted; this tained by Newson tion isotopic subs closer connection ours. For the pair tances and their r For the other ihn bers were conside mentioning that r not completely u values of pair dist inspection of the ture information water molecules 2 ion (Mco^-HzO ' with sufficient ace hypothesis about necessary. In fig. ; 158 Volume 98, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 June 1983 is included. Between the two maxima, at the base of the CP H^O interaction peak, a shoulder is clearly observable at %;2-50 A. Arguing by analogy from the results obtained in CoCI^ [1] andNiCI^ [1,3] solutions, this shoulder is likely to be diagnostic of Co^ Cl" direct contacts. The broad peak around 4.20 4.50 A contains several contributions coming from order phenomena beyond the ssrst ionic coordination shells. In order to have quantitative information about nearest-neighbour Co2'1' coordination, the high-angle structure function was first analysed [10], since this part of the s i(s) function (from ^5 A"1 on) comes from the shortest pair distances. To this end, a syn- thetic structure function was evaluated by using the modified Debye formula, as is usually done in the analysis of diffraction data from liquids and amor- phous substances; this synthetic function was com- pared with the experimental s /(s) through a least- squares procedure. The terms introduced in the calcu- lations were those describing Co^-H^O, Co^-CP, H^O-H^O, Cr-H20 and Li+-H20 direct interac- tions (the H^O H^O term accounts for various inter- actions within the first coordination shells of the cat- ions, between water molecules in subsequent hydra- tion shells and so on). The coordination number of the Cl~ ion was set to the value of 6 suggested by several X-ray and neutron diffraction investigations [3,6,11 ]. As far as the Li"1' ion is concerned, the coor- dination number of 4, obtained by Narten et al. [8] in a combined study by X-ray and neutron diffraction, was adopted; this result was preferred to the one ob- tained by Newsome et al. [l 2] by the neutron diffrac- tion isotopic substitution technique, because of the closer connection of the method used by Narten with ours. For the pairs CI' H^O and Li^ H^O only dis- tances and their mean-square deviations were refined. For the other three terms also the coordination num- bers were considered as variable parameters. It is worth mentioning that most of the refined parameters are not completely unknown; for instance, indicative values of pair distances are known both from direct inspection of the correlation function and from litera- ture information [1,3]. Therefore, the numbers of water molecules and Cl~ ions surrounding the Co24' ion ("Co^-HzO 2n{^ "Co^-cr") can ^e determined with sufficient accuracy. In this calculation no a priori hypothesis about the ionic coordination geometry was necessary. In fig. 3 the high-angle synthetic s i(s) from 05 00 si(s) /\ r^. S.A' 10 12 14 Fig 3. High-angle experimental (...) and model ( ) Structure functions. The "model" i i(.s) is calculated with tlie parame- ters reported in table 1. column 1. tlie best fit (full line) is compared with the experimen- tal one (dots); the final values of the parameters de- scribing the ionic coordinations are given in table 1, column 1. The overall coordination of Co2"*" ions ("CO^'^-H-.O + "co^-cr ^6-5) is slightly greater than 6; the dif- ference, however, is less than 10%. that is, less than the experimental uncertainty estimated for the coor- dination numbers [10]. This calculation thus suggests that the Co2"1' ions are, on tlie average, six-fold coor- Table 1 Mean distances r (A), mean-square deviations o(A) and frequen- cy factors n usedin the final calculations of the synthetic struc- ture functions are given for the interactions describing the ionic environments Standard errors of the refined parame- ters from the computer program are given in parentheses- Col- umn 1 gives the results from the high-angle 5 i(s) analysis: column 2 gives the results from the total s i(s) anah sis Kish-angle s i(s) Total i H.S) ''Co^-HaO 2.099(2) 2.104(4) "Co^-HzO 0.120(2) 0.125(9) "Co^-HzO ' Co^-Cl- 5-5(1) 2.437(5) 5 2.49(1) "Co^-Cl- 0.138(9) 0-16(1) "co^-cr 0.96(9) 1 ^Li^HzO 2-03(2) 2.13(2) "Li'-HzO 0.14(2) 0.20(5) '"cr-HaO "cr-HzO 3.161(3) 0.202(4) 3.145(4) 0.208(4) 159 Volume 98. number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 June 1983 Volume 98, nurobei diluted. Tlie value ofM^-p2+_Q- is very close to 1; it is also vei\ close to tlie \alue "N[2+_Q- proposed in an X-ray diffraction study of a NiC^ solution of very similar composition [3]. In order lo confirm tins conclusion, a complete simulation of the structure function was performed. To tins end. geometric models lor ionic coordination had lo be pioposed in order to calculate contribu- tions fiom medium-range order. The transition to a continuous distribution of distances w as accomplished in ihc usual v. ay [ 1 3 ]. Tlie Cl" ions not bonded to the cations were as- sumed to form octahedral complexes Cl(H;iO)^ [3]. As i egards Co-* ions, following the indications of the i->re\ ions analysis. tlie octaliedral complex Co(H-)0).;CI'1" and llie adi-icent step complexes O.^H-.O)^ and Co( Hi 0)40^ \\ ere considered ihemost probable spe- cies In ici. [3] \\e showed tliat the metliod does not lead lo an accurate detcrniinalion of the amounts of eai-h species since equivalent sets of complexes (i.e. liaMiia the same "\i^_(-i ^aluc) give rise to equally good Ills Tlieielore \\e did nol tiv to evaluate llie percent- age.solTne diffeient complexes. Two extreme cases \\ere e\.nmned:in llie tirsl.onlv the complex Co(H-50)^ Cl4' u as iniioduced into llie calculations: in the second. llie same numhei /;(~ 2+_c-i- \\as obtained through ^'rofC'oU^O)^. 507; ofCoCH^O^Cr- and 257r of Co(Il-,0)4Cl->. Since almost equivalent synthetic .s ;(i) \\ere obtained in the t\\o simulations, only the simplest c.ise (with onl\ Co(H->0);;Cr1') is considered in llie following In addmon 10 the terms mentioned, second-order iniei actions around Co24' ions were also miroduL-ed. For tlie Li4' ion the tetrahedral arrange- ment proposed b\ Narten et al. [8] was assumed. Tlie agreement between experimental (dots) and calculated (full line) structure and correlation func- tions is shown in figs. 1 and 2- The consistency w'itli liie experiment of a coordination model in which ;;C^;+ ^ i- is nearly 1. is apparent. In table 1. column 2. the siruciural parameters of the ionic coordination obtained tliiough the filling procedure are given. The \alues toiind in the previous fit are on the whole con- Inmed. tlie dilferences between the two columns rep- iesenl llie real uncertainties of the parameters better than the siandaid errors given by the computer pro- gram and wlncli are reported in parentheses [101. The gieatest uncertainties are in the distances Lr'" H->0 and C'o^ CT", presumably because of the low weight of their contributions to the synthetic s i(s); however. all the parameter values fall in the range of experimen- tal results given in the literature. The quantitative analysis of diffractometric data shows that Ni24" and Co2'1' have almost the same tendency to bind chloride ions at the solution composition examined here. In order to acquire an independent description of the cationic environment, EXAFS measurements on the Co K edge were also carried out on the same sample. A wider EXAFS investigation on the state of Co2"'" ions in CoCl-> solution is in progress. In the present paper, only the results of a qualitative analysis are re- ported; this is based on the comparison of EXAFS data from similar NiCI-, and CoCh solutions and from the hydrated crystal of NiClyoH^O. The de- tails of experimental procedure and data treatment have been described [13]. The EXAFS spectrum nor- malized on a per atom basis with a standard procedure was Fourier transformed to obtain the radial function F'{r). Likewise in X-ray data analysis, this step does not require any a priori structural hypothesis. The IF(r)l a . ; " b\ '.N- c r A ^t... ^.r^ magnitude \F(r)\ two solutions are tered around 1.61 est-neighbour coc the maxima of th analysis conies fn experiments [4,1 The quantitati not immediate, a affect the \F(r)\ i the right-hand sit function of the c lions from four v two chloride ioni hand, the radial fi manifestly Me C mainly in the spi of the main peak of the two ions t shown by the co behaviour are no The structural working conditic tlie techniques ei Cl" complexatio ion concentratio the choice of the centration of Cl" has been found r tion than Nad [ two points are re Fig. 4. Fourier transform \F(r)} of EXAFS data from CoCla- LiCI (a) and NiCI; -Lid (b) solutions of similar composition. and from crystalline NiCl^-oH^O (c). 160 Volume 98, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 June 1983 magnitude |.F'(r)i of the Fourier transforms for the two solutions are shown in fig. 4. The main peak, cen- tered around 1.60 1.65 A, described the cation near- est-neighbour coordination; the different position of the maxima of the first peak in X-ray and EXAFS analysis conies from phase-shift phenomena in EXAFS experiments [4,13]. The quantitative interpretation of the main peak is not immediate, as residual errors from data treatment affect the \F(r)\ and heavily influence the r region at the right-hand side of the peak. However, the radial function of the crystal clearly shows the contribu- tions from four water molecules (at 2.05 A) and from two chloride ions (at 2.36 A) [4,14]. On the other hand, the radial functions of the solutions do not show manifestly Me Cl pairs and differ one from the other mainly in the spurious details at the right-hand side of the main peak. This supports the idea that neither of the two ions tends to bind Cl~ ions in the amount shown by the crystal and that the differences in their behaviour are not great. The structural similarity of Co2"1' and Ni24" in our working conditions is confirmed within the limits of tlie techniques employed. The possibility of different Cl~ complexations may be connected with lower cat- ion concentration and greater C^/Me2"1' ratios. Even the choice of the electrolyte that increases the con- centration of Cl~ ions might be of importance; HC1 has been found more effective in causing complexa- tion than Nad [15]. Further investigations of these two points are required. Acknowledgement Calculations were carried out at the Centre di Calcolo Elettronico of the Cagliari University. References [ 1 ] M. Magini. J. head.ce:title: X-ray investigation of CoCl bonding in a concentrated aqueous solution of CoCl2 and LiCl

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A concentrated CO(II) solution with a Cl−/Co2+ ratio of≈4 was examined by X-ray diffraction. The Fourier-transformed scattering data indicated inner complex formation between Co2+ and Cl−ions. The overall coordination of Co2+ ions is very close to 6 and the average number of bonded Cl− ions per cobalt atom was found to be nearly 1. The similarity of this result to the one obtained from a solution of NiCl2 of equal concentration is discussed. This result was also checked through EXAFS measurements.
